title-group.article-title: Commentary on Educational Outcomes Associated With Providing a Comprehensive Guidelines Program About Nursing Care of Preterm Neonates Receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition

body.p: In the early postnatal days, optimal nutrition is as essential as respiratory and cardiac support, especially for very low birth weight (VLBW) infants (<1,500 g) and extremely low birth weight infants (ELBW) infants (<1,000 g). The goals of evidence-based early nutritional recommendations focus on imitating intrauterine growth rates, preventing early weight loss and avoiding catabolism (Ehrenkranz, 2007). When these goals are met, malnutrition, growth failure, and growth restriction are minimized. Mortality and morbidity rates for premature infants have improved over the years along with nutritional strategies, but premature infants still demonstrate growth restriction at discharge which may affect later neurocognitive outcomes. Studies both in the United States and internationally have reported better catch-up growth and neurodevelopmental outcomes in VLBW infants when early, aggressive parenteral and enteral nutritional strategies are initiated within the first days of life (Ehrenkranz et al., 2006; Martin et al., 2009; Poindexter, Langer, Dusick, & Ehrenkranz, 2006; Senterre & Rigo, 2011; Stephens et al., 2009).

The provision of high-quality nutrients during the first few weeks of life is often challenged by the infant’s immaturity and associated problems of prematurity. Initially, nutrition is given via the parenteral route until the infant is hemodynamically stable and then enteral feedings are slowly introduced. Aggressive parenteral nutritional strategies include the use of amino acids and essential fatty acids administered during the early postnatal phase (van den Akker, Vlaardingerbroek, & van Goudoever, 2010). Amino acids have a positive effect on short-term growth and diminish mortality and morbidity; essential fatty acids are important for brain development (Carlson, 2009; Krohn & Koletzko, 2006). Amino acids are initiated within hours of birth, but the initiation of lipid emulsions at birth remains controversial (Simmer & Rao, 2005). The Committee on Nutrition of the American Academy of Pediatrics (1985) recommends a caloric intake of 80 to 100 kcal/kg/day for infants parenterally fed, with a protein intake of 3.5 to 4 g/kg/day. As outlined in the educational program developed by Al-Rafay and Al-Sharkawy, nurses play a pivotal role in the management of an infant on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Close monitoring of the neonate on TPN is needed to prevent such complications as catheter-related infections, fluid and electrolyte imbalances, and extravasation injuries.

Despite compelling evidence, nutritional practice variations continue to exist between institutions, practitioners, and nurses throughout the world (Martin et al., 2009; Stephens et al., 2009). These inconsistencies can result in suboptimal nutrition, placing vulnerable neonates at risk for impaired growth, sepsis, longer exposure to volutrauma and barotrauma associated with mechanical ventilation, increased oxygen toxicity, underdevelopment of organs such as the intestines and brain, increased duration of hospitalization and neurocognitive impairment at 18-months corrected age (Ehrenkranz et al., 2006; van den Akker et al., 2010). Education is one solution to improving knowledge and practice in the area of neonatal nutrition.

In their study, Al-Rafay and Al-Sharkawy demonstrated that an educational program on the management of preterm infants on parenteral nutrition affected both nurses’ knowledge and practice outcomes. Although their study only evaluated nursing care of late preterm infants (born between 35 and 37 weeks), the major concepts covered in the program are applicable to all preterm infants. The authors used multiple teaching strategies for knowledge acquisition. Strategies included didactic lectures, small group discussions, audiovisual media, and simulation training. The multiple educational strategies addressed the different types of learning styles. The authors showed nurses were able to acquire evidence-based knowledge and apply it to their nursing practice of preterm infants on TPN. After successfully achieving improvements in knowledge and practice, it is imperative to establish mechanisms to ensure sustainability. An example of a mechanism would be monthly rounds or bedside audits of nursing care of infants on TPN. This process helps to identify areas that may require retraining.

The study also highlighted the need for an interprofessional approach to the nutritional management of preterm infants receiving parenteral nutrition. This supports a recommendation by the ESPGHAN Committee on Nutrition (2005) for the implementation of nutritional support teams in pediatric critical care units (Agostoni et al., 2005). Some of the roles of a nutritional support team include the identification of infants at risk for malnutrition, to ensure effective nutritional management for high-risk infants, ongoing education of staff, to develop a nutritional plan for the infant for home upon discharge, and to monitor and evaluate practice. The implementation of such teams improves patient outcomes, decreases cost of care, and illuminates the need for optimal nutrition for the most vulnerable patients.

Al-Rafay and Al-Sharkawy’s work lies within both the quality improvement (QI) and research domains. Research as defined by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (2002) is “a systematic investigation, including research development, testing and evaluation, designed to develop or contribute to generalizable knowledge” whereas quality improvement is “a process by which individuals work together to improve systems and processes with the intention to improve outcomes” (Newhouse, Pettit, Poe, & Rocco, 2006, p. 212). Quality improvement, evidence-based practice, and research are interrelated and support the foundation for nursing practice. Research and quality improvement produce desired outcomes but have a different relationship with knowledge. Research generates new knowledge and quality improvement incorporates it (Shirey et al., 2011).

From the research perspective, the study has several methodological issues. The study was conducted in a single setting; it lacks a comparison group; all nurses in the unit were assigned to the study and, therefore, no random assignment; and bias is present. Another issue is the sample of preterm infants. The authors sampled only late preterm infants (35-37 weeks) requiring medical interventions. In many instances, these infants are not candidates for total parenteral nutrition and when initiated have TPN for only a brief period of time. The most fragile and vulnerable infants were not sampled. Despite these issues, their study increases the awareness that NICU nurses require a strong foundation on the nutritional management of high-risk neonates on parenteral nutrition and a clear understanding of parenteral nutrition’s short- and long-term benefits and consequences for the preterm infant. A targeted educational program that uses multiple teaching strategies is one solution to improve nurses’ knowledge and practice in the care of preterm neonates receiving total parenteral nutrition.
